title: NIO, Novavax, Lockheed, Yandex, First Horizon: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today; China's NIO is planning a secondary listing in Hong Kong; Results are due from Novavax
text:
* Defense stocks were ticking higher ahead of the bell, as European nations have signaled a new push to build up their military strength and to send aid to Ukraine. Northrop Grumman climbed 4.5%, Lockheed Martin gained 3.8%, L3Harris Technologies rose 3.6% and Raytheon Technologies added 4.5%.

* Yandex, a search-engine company that provides services in Russia, Ukraine and other countries in the region, plunged 21% premarket.

* U.S.-traded shares of BP dropped 8.2% premarket. The British energy giant said Sunday it will exit its nearly 20% stake in Russian government-controlled oil producer Rosneft, days after it was pressured to unload the holding by U.K. officials.

* Toronto-Dominion Bank said Monday that it is accelerating its long-term growth strategy in the U.S. by acquiring Tennessee-based First Horizon for $13.4 billion. First Horizon shares shot 32% higher premarket, and TD Bank nudged down 1.2%.

* Berkshire Hathaway class B shares slipped 0.3% premarket. The conglomerate headed by Warren Buffett reported $90 billion in net earnings in 2021, a record, thanks in part to its giant stock portfolio. Berkshire owns 5.6% of Apple, a stake valued at $161.2 billion at the end of the yearâ€”up more than $40 billion from the year before.

* Momentive Global dropped 2.4% off hours. Zendesk said it terminated its deal with the parent of web-survey company SurveyMonkey after its shareholders rejected the agreement at a stockholder meeting.

* Novavax, Zoom Video Communications, HP, Workday, PubMatic and SmileDirectClub are among the companies reporting earnings Monday.

* London-listed shares of Russian companies plunged, with Sberbank, the country's largest lender, down close to 70%. Gazprom fell 50% and Rosneft lost over 40%.

Chart of the Day

* Powerful Western sanctions rocked Russia's financial system and triggered a spiral in the ruble, drawing the central bank into an emergency doubling of interest rates.
